billEvents.eventText: REFERRED TO CORPORATIONS, AUTHORITIES AND COMMISSIONS

title: Permits elimination of liability of directors of certain not-for-profit corporations to the corporation or its members
summary: Authorizes the certificate of incorporation of a not-for-profit corporation to eliminate or limit the personal liability of directors to the corporation or its members provided that liability for acts or omissions which were in bad faith, intentional misconduct or a knowing violation of law shall not be limited or eliminated; does not apply to medical or dental corporations.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2121

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the not-for-profit corporation law, in relation to duty of
directors and available relief for breach thereof

PURPOSE:
To permit not-for-profit corporations to protect their
directors from personal liability for a breach of duty except
where a director's actions were in bad faith, involved
intentional misconduct, knowing violation of law, or personal gain,
financial or otherwise.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
This bill would add to Section 402 of the Not-for-Profit
Corporation Law a new subsection (d) to provide that the
certificate of incorporation may limit a director's personal
liability to the corporation or its members for damages for any
breach of duty as director, unless the director's acts or
omissions were in bad faith, involved intentional misconduct, a
knowing violation of law or personal gain, financial or
otherwise. Section 720 (a) (1) of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law
would be amended to conform with the possible limitation of
liability provided under the new Section 402 (d).  This bill
will not apply to corporations organized pursuant to Article 43
of the insurance law.

JUSTIFICATION:
When the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law ("N-PCL") §  720-a was enacted
in 1986, the legislature addressed the need to protect volunteer
directors, officers and trustees of not-for-profit charitable
organizations against third party tort claims. Directors, officers and
trustees of not-for-profit corporations are frequently named as
defendants, regardless of culpability, because they are either perceived
as having greater financial resources than the nonprofit organizations
they serve or are perceived as being more likely to settle a frivolous
suit than to contest the suit, due to their role as volunteers
in not-for-profit organizations, insufficient funds and their
status in the community.

Unfortunately, the legislature
limited the protection of N-PCL §  720-a to those individuals who
served as directors, officers and trustees of Internal Revenue
Code Section 501 (c) (3) organizations and limited that
protection to third party claims. This bill would provide
protection to directors of all not-for-profit corporations against
claims by the corporation or its members. Chapter 367 of the
Laws of 1987 amended the Business Corporation Law ("BCL")
(adding new section (b) to BCL §402) to provide that
corporations could, by provision in the certificate of incorporation,

limit the liability of directors to corporations or
shareholders for any breach of duty unless the director's actions
were in bad faith or involved intentional misconduct, a knowing
violation of law or financial or other profit by the
director.

The BCL legislation was in part a response to director's
legitimate concerns regarding unjustified exposure to personal
liability for good faith management actions. This concern for
exposure diminished the ability of corporations to recruit
directors, undercut directors' ability to act based upon
corporate interests as opposed to acting primarily to minimize
potential liability, and threatened to drive corporations out of
New York to states with statutes more favorable to directors.
All of these concerns apply to a much greater extent to
directors who serve on boards of not-for-profit corporations. They
perform
valuable functions for the community and the State of New York. Indeed,
because not-for-profit directors usually serve without compensation
and because
many not-for-profit corporations can ill afford appropriate levels of
directors' liability insurance or provide adequate indemnification, the
concerns
of directors over litigation, however frivolous, are substantially
heightened.

The perception of exposure to personal liability has had
a detrimental
effect on the ability of not-for-profit corporations to recruit
directors. This
bill will ease this problem. The exclusion of protection for acts that
are in
bad faith, involve intentional misconduct, a knowing violation of law,
or
personal gain, minimizes any potential detriment to the corporation or
its
members.
These benefits may only be extended to directors by amendment
of the certificate of incorporation and under Section 802 of the N-PCL,
members must authorize such amendments if there are any members
entitled to vote
thereon. Many other states, including Delaware and Pennsylvania, provide
protection for directors of not-for-profit corporations similar to that
provided for in this bill.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately.
